option.name: description
option.value:
This course provides a series of katas to get familiar with Apache Beam.
Apache Beam website – https://beam.apache.org/

option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
Hello Beam Pipeline

Apache Beam is an open source, unified model for defining both batch and streaming data-parallel processing pipelines. Using one of the open source Beam SDKs, you build a program that defines the pipeline. The pipeline is then executed by one of Beam’s supported distributed processing back-ends, which include Apache Apex, Apache Flink, Apache Spark, and Google Cloud Dataflow.

Beam is particularly useful for Embarrassingly Parallel data processing tasks, in which the problem can be decomposed into many smaller bundles of data that can be processed independently and in parallel. You can also use Beam for Extract, Transform, and Load (ETL) tasks and pure data integration. These tasks are useful for moving data between different storage media and data sources, transforming data into a more desirable format, or loading data onto a new system.

To learn more about Apache Beam, refer to Apache Beam Overview.


The first kata is to create a simple pipeline that takes a hardcoded input element "Hello Beam"



Hardcoded input can be created using Create

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
ParDo

ParDo is a Beam transform for generic parallel processing. The ParDo processing paradigm is similar to the “Map” phase of a Map/Shuffle/Reduce-style algorithm: a ParDo transform considers each element in the input PCollection, performs some processing function (your user code) on that element, and emits zero, one, or multiple elements to an output PCollection.

For this task, please write a simple ParDo that maps the input element by multiplying it by 10.



Use ParDo with DoFn

option.name: possibleAnswer
text
descriptionText
option.value:
ParDo OneToMany

For this task, please write a ParDo that maps each input sentence into words tokenized by whitespace (" ").



Hint: You can call DoFn.ProcessContext.output(..) multiple times in a ParDo.

option.name: possibleAnswer
text
descriptionText
option.value:
MapElements

The Beam SDKs provide language-specific ways to simplify how you provide your DoFn implementation.

MapElements can be used to simplify DoFn that maps an element to another element (one to one).

In this task, we are going to implement a simple map function that multiplies all input elements by 5 using MapElements.into(...).via(...).



Use MapElements.into(...).via(...)

option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
FlatMapElements

The Beam SDKs provide language-specific ways to simplify how you provide your DoFn implementation.

FlatMapElements can be used to simplify DoFn that maps an element to multiple elements (one to many).

In this task, we are going to implement a function that maps each input sentence into words tokenized by whitespace (" ") using FlatMapElements.into(...).via(...).



Use FlatMapElements.into(...).via(...)

option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
GroupByKey

GroupByKey is a Beam transform for processing collections of key/value pairs. It’s a parallel reduction operation, analogous to the Shuffle phase of a Map/Shuffle/Reduce-style algorithm. The input to GroupByKey is a collection of key/value pairs that represents a multimap, where the collection contains multiple pairs that have the same key, but different values. Given such a collection, you use GroupByKey to collect all of the values associated with each unique key.

In this task, we are going to implement a GroupByKey transform that groups words by its first letter.



Refer to KV and GroupByKey to solve this problem.

option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
CoGroupByKey

CoGroupByKey performs a relational join of two or more key/value PCollections that have the same key type.

In this task, we are going to implement a CoGroupByKey transform that join words by its first alphabetical letter, and then produces the toString() representation of the WordsAlphabet model.



Refer to CoGroupByKey, TupleTag, and CoGbkResult.

option.name: possibleAnswer
descriptionText
option.value:
Combine - Simple Function

Combine is a Beam transform for combining collections of elements or values in your data. When you apply a Combine transform, you must provide the function that contains the logic for combining the elements or values. The combining function should be commutative and associative, as the function is not necessarily invoked exactly once on all values with a given key. Because the input data (including the value collection) may be distributed across multiple workers, the combining function might be called multiple times to perform partial combining on subsets of the value collection.

Simple combine operations, such as sums, can usually be implemented as a simple function.

In this task, we are going to implement the summation of numbers using Combine.globally(SerializableFunction).



Implement the SerializableFunction.apply method that performs the summation of the Iterable.

option.name: possibleAnswer
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Combine - CombineFn

Combine is a Beam transform for combining collections of elements or values in your data. When you apply a Combine transform, you must provide the function that contains the logic for combining the elements or values. The combining function should be commutative and associative, as the function is not necessarily invoked exactly once on all values with a given key. Because the input data (including the value collection) may be distributed across multiple workers, the combining function might be called multiple times to perform partial combining on subsets of the value collection.

Complex combination operations might require you to create a subclass of CombineFn that has an accumulation type distinct from the input/output type. You should use CombineFn if the combine function requires a more sophisticated accumulator, must perform additional pre- or post-processing, might change the output type, or takes the key into account.

In this task, we are going to implement the average of numbers using Combine.CombineFn.



Extend the Combine.CombineFn class that counts the average of the number.

option.name: possibleAnswer
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Combine - BinaryCombineFn

Combine is a Beam transform for combining collections of elements or values in your data. When you apply a Combine transform, you must provide the function that contains the logic for combining the elements or values. The combining function should be commutative and associative, as the function is not necessarily invoked exactly once on all values with a given key. Because the input data (including the value collection) may be distributed across multiple workers, the combining function might be called multiple times to perform partial combining on subsets of the value collection.

BinaryCombineFn is used for implementing combiners that are more easily expressed as binary operations.

In this task, we are going to implement the summation of BigInteger using Combine.BinaryCombineFn.



Extend the Combine.BinaryCombineFn class that counts the sum of the number.

option.name: possibleAnswer
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Combine - Combine PerKey

After creating a keyed PCollection (for example, by using a GroupByKey transform), a common pattern is to combine the collection of values associated with each key into a single, merged value. This pattern of a GroupByKey followed by merging the collection of values is equivalent to Combine PerKey transform. The combine function you supply to Combine PerKey must be an associative reduction function or a subclass of CombineFn.

In this task, we are going to implement the sum of scores per player using Combine.perKey.



Use Combine.perKey(GlobalCombineFn).
Extend the Combine.BinaryCombineFn class that counts the sum of the number.

option.name: possibleAnswer
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Flatten

Flatten is a Beam transform for PCollection objects that store the same data type. Flatten merges multiple PCollection objects into a single logical PCollection.

In this task, we are going to implement a Flatten transform that merges two PCollection of words into a single PCollection.



Refer to Flatten to solve this problem.

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Partition

Partition is a Beam transform for PCollection objects that store the same data type. Partition splits a single PCollection into a fixed number of smaller collections. Partition divides the elements of a PCollection according to a partitioning function that you provide. The partitioning function contains the logic that determines how to split up the elements of the input PCollection into each resulting partition PCollection.

In this task, we are going to implement a Partition transform that splits a PCollection of numbers into two PCollections. The first PCollection contains numbers greater than 100, and the second PCollection contains the remaining numbers.



Refer to Partition to solve this problem.

option.name: possibleAnswer
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Filter using ParDo

In this task, we are going to implement a filter function that filters out the even numbers by using DoFn.



Use ParDo with DoFn and only output the intended element.

option.name: possibleAnswer
descriptionText
option.value:
Filter

The Beam SDKs provide language-specific ways to simplify how you provide your DoFn implementation.

In this task, we are going to implement a filter function that filters out the odd numbers by using Filter.



Use Filter.by(...)

option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
Aggregation - Count

In this task, we are going to count the number of elements from an input.



Use Count

option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
Aggregation - Sum

In this task, we are going to compute the sum of all elements from an input.



Use Sum

option.name: descriptionText

Aggregation - Mean

In this task, we are going to compute the mean/average of all elements from an input.



Use Mean

option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
Aggregation - Min

In this task, we are going to compute the minimum of the elements from an input.



Use Min

option.name: text
descriptionText

Aggregation - Max

In this task, we are going to compute the maximum of the elements from an input.



Use Max

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Word Count Pipeline

This kata is to create a pipeline that counts the number of words.

For this task, please output the count of each word in the following format:

    word:count
    ball:5
    book:3



Refer to your lessons above.
